title: nt.number theory - How smooth can this be?
body: If $a$ is an even integer then how smooth can $a^2-1$ be? Approximately how many integers in $a\in[0,t]$ are there such that $a^2-1$ is $k$ -smooth? nt.number-theory smoothness Share Cite Improve this question Follow asked Jul 5, 2020 at 23:58 VS. 1,846 1 1 gold badge 12 12 silver badges 27 27 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 5 1 $\begingroup$ The numbers of $prime(i)$-smooth $4n^2-1$'s for $n \le 10^6$ start $0, 1, 3, 6, 9, 15, 22, 35, 56, 76$ (i.e. there is one $3$-smooth, namely $n=1$, there are three $5$-smooth (including $n=2$ and $13$), etc). This sequence does not seem to be in OEIS. $\endgroup$ Robert Israel –  Robert Israel 2020-07-06 01:19:21 +00:00 Commented Jul 6, 2020 at 1:19 4 $\begingroup$ Since $a^2-1$ is $k$-smooth if and only if $a-1,a+1$ are $k$-smooth, the latter question is almost answered by Stormer's theorem en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St%C3%B8rmer%27s_theorem , which gives a bound exponential in $\pi(k)$. Presumably the proof of that theorem adapts to numbers separated by 2 rather than 1. $\endgroup$ Terry Tao –  Terry Tao 2020-07-06 03:46:43 +00:00 Commented Jul 6, 2020 at 3:46 2 $\begingroup$ There is a PDF of Klazar from 2010 on this topic, which covers the case of smooth numbers differing by 2. It should come up in a search on Stormers Theorem. Gerhard "Is Typographically Challenged At Present" Paseman, 2020.07.05. $\endgroup$ Gerhard Paseman –  Gerhard Paseman 2020-07-06 05:03:48 +00:00 Commented Jul 6, 2020 at 5:03 1 $\begingroup$ Referring theorem $1$ in kam.mff.cuni.cz/~klazar/stormer.pdf ? $\endgroup$ VS. –  VS. 2020-07-06 09:20:27 +00:00 Commented Jul 6, 2020 at 9:20 2 $\begingroup$ $26^2-1$ is $5$-smooth, $244^2-1$ is $7$-smooth, $1574^2-1$ is $13$-smooth. $\endgroup$ Gerry Myerson –  Gerry Myerson 2020-07-06 09:48:00 +00:00 Commented Jul 6, 2020 at 9:48 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
